title: Jacinto Elá
text:
Pedro Jacinto Elá Eyene (born 2 May 1982), known as Elá, is an <a href="Equatorial%20Guinea">Equatoguinean</a> retired <a href="Association%20football">footballer</a> who played as a <a href="Midfielder%23Winger">right winger</a>.
Club career.
Born in <a href="A%C3%B1isoc">Añisoc</a>, Elá moved to <a href="Barcelona">Barcelona</a> at the age of ten with his parents. He played most of his <a href="Youth%20system">youth football</a> with <a href="RCD%20Espanyol">RCD Espanyol</a> (five years), being selected to <a href="Spain%20national%20youth%20football%20team">Spain's youth teams</a> whilst with the club and also helping <a href="RCD%20Espanyol%20B">the reserves</a> promote to <a href="Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20B">Segunda División B</a> in 2000; the following year, he won the <a href="Copa%20del%20Rey%20Juvenil%20de%20F%C3%BAtbol">Copa del Rey Juvenil</a> with <a href="RCD%20Espanyol%20Juvenil">the juniors</a>.
On 24 July 1999, Elá made his competitive debut with Espanyol's first team, appearing in a <a href="UEFA%20Intertoto%20Cup">UEFA Intertoto Cup</a> game against <a href="Montpellier%20HSC">Montpellier HSC</a> in <a href="France">France</a>, as a 70th-minute <a href="Substitute%20%28association%20football%29">substitute</a> (<a href="1999%20UEFA%20Intertoto%20Cup">1–2 loss</a>). It was his only appearance for the <a href="Catalonia">Catalans</a>.
In the 2001 off-season, Elá signed for <a href="Southampton%20F.C.">Southampton</a> in England, penning a three-year contract after turning down <a href="Coventry%20City%20F.C.">Coventry City</a>. During his spell he never appeared officially with the <a href="Premier%20League">Premier League</a> side, being limited to <a href="Southampton%20F.C.%20Academy">reserve team</a> football; additionally, in the 2001–02 season, he suffered a serious <a href="knee">knee</a> injury.
In 2002, Elá was loaned to <a href="H%C3%A9rcules%20CF">Hércules CF</a> in the Spanish third level, under former <a href="Sporting%20de%20Gij%C3%B3n">Sporting de Gijón</a> and <a href="CD%20Tenerife">CD Tenerife</a> player <a href="Felipe%20Mi%C3%B1ambres">Felipe Miñambres</a>. In March 2003, in a <a href="Exhibition%20game">friendly match</a> with <a href="Elche%20CF">Elche CF</a>, he suffered another severe injury to his knee, after a hard tackle by Raúl Pérez; upon his return to the Saints, he continued to appear exclusively for the second team.
In August 2005, Elá signed for <a href="Dundee%20F.C.">Dundee</a> of the <a href="Scottish%20Football%20League%20First%20Division">Scottish Football League First Division</a>. His output consisted of two league matches, plus two appearances in the <a href="Scottish%20Challenge%20Cup">Challenge Cup</a> and one in the <a href="Scottish%20League%20Cup">League Cup</a>, going scoreless in the process; he left the club in late November.
From 2005 until his retirement in 2010 at the age of only 28, Elá played exclusively in amateur football, the sole exception being eight third level games for <a href="UDA%20Gramenet">UDA Gramenet</a> in the <a href="2006%E2%80%9307%20Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20B">2006–07 campaign</a>.
Post-retirement / Personal life.
After retiring, Elá returned to Barcelona and started his own clothing line, Malabona (a combination of "<a href="Malabo">Malabo</a>" and "Barcelona"), working alongside his wife Esther in the design of T-shirts and all kinds of fashion clothes, which were then sold via the <a href="internet">internet</a>.
His younger brother, <a href="Ruslan%20El%C3%A1">Ruslan</a>, was also a footballer. A <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29">defender</a>, he represented the <a href="Equatorial%20Guinea%20national%20football%20team">Equatoguinean national team</a>.
